abstract.text: A type representing a trait in a trait collection.

inlineContent.text: All traits contained in a

The example below defines a new trait that holds an

Defining
is the minimum requirement to conform to this protocol. The
must be constant.
The best candidates for trait values are simple scalars:
and
. You can also use lightweight objects as trait values, but these are less efficient than simple scalars. Examples of lightweight objects include

, or a composite of similarly lightweight objects. Make sure the default value never changes, preferably by making the object immutable. The system frequently checks trait values for equality, so classes need an efficient implementation of
If you use your custom trait to implement custom dynamic colors, implement
and return
. Returning
tells the system to update and redraw views automatically when the trait changes. The system responds to changes to your trait similar to changes in system traits contained in
. Changes to traits that affect color appearance are more expensive, so opt in to this behavior only when necessary, and change such traits infrequently.
A trait type serves as a unique key, identifying a trait within a trait collection. Methods such as
and
take a trait type to identify the trait in a collection.

content.text: Traits in both Swift and Objective-C

inlineContent.text: If you need to access traits from both Swift and Objective-C code, create a type conforming to
in both languages. To define a trait that’s accessible from both Swift and Objective-C, follow these guidelines :
In Swift, define a structure that conforms to
In Objective-C, define an
subclass that conforms to
, or
Implement
, and
, and make the values the same in Objective-C and Swift.
If your trait holds an object value, make the class visible to both Swift and Objective-C.
If your trait holds a fundamental value type, make your Objective-C types correspond to Swift types, as in the following table:
Swift
Objective-C
For Swift
values, Objective-C uses 0 for
and 1 for
If your Swift trait uses an optional type for the
, Objective-C represents a Swift
value with a special Objective-C constant. The table below lists the Objective-C values that correspond to a Swift
value.

In Objective-C, your trait value may require an
subclass if your data model exceeds the simple scalars of
and

. To use this value in Swift, import your Objective-C class into Swift, and use it for the value of your custom trait in both languages. Other than bridging with Objective-C, avoid using reference types for Swift trait values.
You can prevent Swift from importing your Objective-C class name by applying the
macro to your Objective-C interface. This macro allows you to name your Swift trait structure with the same name as your Objective-C trait class.
The example below defines a trait in Objective-C, with a custom
type for a trait value.
The following code example shows the definition of a Swift trait so that UIKit recognizes it as the same trait as defined above in Objective-C:

code: // The NS_REFINED_FOR_SWIFT macro allows this struct to have
// the same name as the Objective-C trait class.

inlineContent.text: The

macro makes your Objective-C class available in Swift by prepending double underscores to the class name. You can use this to make your Swift implementation call your Objective-C class properties. For more details, refer to

abstract.text: A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
Use the `NS_REFINED_FOR_SWIFT` macro to change how an API is imported into Swift.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Improving Objective-C API Declarations for Swift

abstract.text: The basic type for floating-point scalar values in Core Graphics and related frameworks.
A representation of a specific point in time, for use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A value indicating that a requested item couldn’t be found or doesn’t exist.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the receiver and a given object are equal.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Registers a list of traits to observe and a closure to execute when one of the observed traits changes.
A collection of data that represents the environment for an individual element in your app’s user interface.
A type representing a trait in a trait collection.
A type representing a trait in a trait collection.

value.text: A static, plain-text Unicode string object.
A representation of a specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.
